body: The donor whose $350 million gift will be critical in building Cornell University's new high-tech graduate school on Roosevelt Island is Atlantic Philanthropies, whose founder, Charles F. Feeney, is a Cornell alumnus who made billions of dollars through the Duty Free Shoppers Group. Mr. Feeney, 80, has spent much of the last three decades giving
title: Cornell Alumnus Behind $350 Million Gift to Build Science School in the City

body: Stanford University abruptly dropped out of the intense international competition to build an innovative science graduate school in New York City, releasing its decision on Friday afternoon. A short time later, its main rival in the contest, Cornell, announced a $350 million gift -- the largest in its history -- to underwrite its bid. The twin
title: Stanford Ends Effort to Build New York Arm

To that may soon be added most heavily fingerprinted. Since September, Afghanistan has been the only country to fingerprint and
title: Inside the Times

body: The developer Bruce C. Ratner unveiled the design Thursday for what would be the world's tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 32-story residential building in Brooklyn at the corner of Flatbush Avenue and Dean Street in the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project. The 350-unit building would use varying rectangular shapes, colors and glass to break
title: CITY ROOM; A Design for Atlantic Yards' Prefab Tower

body: Think of it as ''American Idol'' for policy wonks and economic development types. So western New York is heralding ''bi-national logistics,'' energy, health and life sciences; the Mohawk Valley is vowing to reinvent itself through advanced high-tech manufacturing; the North Country claims it will ''lead the economic renaissance of New York's small
title: In a Job-Creation Experiment, New York Regions Are Vying for Development Cash

body: MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG is not, by his own admission, much of a wordsmith. He is forever mispronouncing names -- even those of his own commissioners. He is impatient with speechwriters. And he rarely, if ever, practices his remarks. ''His mentality,'' concedes his top speechwriter, Francis S. Barry, ''is not one of rehearsal.'' But despite his
title: Data-Crunching Mayor Now Sees Power in Words

body: The site of the Brooklyn Navy Yard has hosted Lenape Indians and Riveting Rosies, Hollywood royalty and lecherous seafarers, Brooklynites and Breuckelenites. On Thursday, in the long shadow of a rusted, deserted machine shop on the Navy Yard's 300-acre grounds, a four-story center, dedicated to the site's forebears and present occupants, will
title: A Glimpse of a Shipbuilding, and Hell-Raising, Past

body: New York City officials have been dreaming for months about a new graduate school bearing a prestigious brand name like Cornell or Stanford. But what about Amity University? Amity, an Indian university with campuses in Dubai and London, submitted one of seven bids for the city's support in building a school of engineering and applied sciences by
title: By Deadline, 7 Bids in Science School Contest

body: Stanford University's proposed graduate school of science on Roosevelt Island carries a $2.5 billion price tag, the university said Wednesday, more than double its estimate just weeks ago. Stanford is a leading contender in the Bloomberg administration's competition to create a new school of applied sciences that officials hope will prompt the
title: Stanford's Estimated Cost For Science School Doubles

body: When one of the biggest real estate developments in Brooklyn was stalled two years ago, its owner turned to the city government for help, seeking $20 million in financing. Nearly 50 projects were applying for a small number of aid packages at the time, but this one, City Point, had a prominent supporter. ''The future of Downtown Brooklyn depends on
title: From Brooklyn Office, Mixing Clout and Charity

body: With less than two weeks left to apply in the competition for $400 million in land and subsidies to build a science and engineering graduate school in New York City, some of the world's great universities continue to change plans and jockey for position, and there is a growing view among them that Cornell and Stanford have emerged as the favorites.
title: 2 Top Suitors Are Emerging For New School Of Engineering

body: Among the 275 tenants filling four million square feet of leasable space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard -- now in the midst of its biggest expansion since World War II -- are any number of industries that do not easily evoke the imagery of ''On the Waterfront.'' These are businesses where fine art is warehoused, where antiques are restored, where
title: BIG CITY; One Day, Maybe, Artisanal Train Cars

body: AN October rain was pelting down on the overgrown and under-loved slice of the Village formally known as St. Vincent's Triangle Park. At its apex, an ugly three-story brick building still shielded the gargantuan oxygen tanks that once pumped life into the bitterly missed St. Vincent's Hospital, which succumbed to bankruptcy in 2010. From the squat
title: A Park, a Memorial, a Debate

For several years, in a stunt that became something of an artwork in its own right, the curator Massimiliano Gioni presented himself at public
title: Hanging With Cattelan

author: E-mail: habitats@nytimes.com
body: THE leafy streets of Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, are lined with gracious brownstones and town houses built in the 19th century for well-to-do families who appreciated their stately proportions and exquisite detailing. Interspersed with these showstoppers are more modest three-story apartment buildings, home to the servants who tended to those grand
title: HABITATS | PROSPECT HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; Inside a Plain Brick Wrapper

body: New York is a changeling, a different city to everyone who passes through. The premiere of the fall TV season will reflect that: Just last month, a record 23 prime-time shows filmed here, thanks in part to recent tax breaks. In sound stages from the Chelsea Piers to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, designers rebuilt the landscape to fit plot lines, making
title: For Prime Time, Sets and the City

body: Once upon a time in New York, the Brooklyn Navy Yard bustled with ships, and an airport called Idlewild was home to a terminal for Pan American World Airways, or Pan Am. Those days are long gone. But on Monday morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stood in the busy Navy Yard, flanked by women dressed in bright blue stewardesses' uniforms with
title: Mayor Praises Growth in Film and TV Jobs

body: WHEN the developers of Atlantic Terrace, an 80-unit co-op in Fort Greene, began planning, they envisioned occupants reflecting the populace on the sidewalks of Brooklyn -- that is, diverse in all ways, but especially economically. That meant even the wealthiest buyers would be living side by side with those of moderate and low incomes. The
title: POSTING; Blurring the Wealth Boundary

body: When Luke Babcock Keller, 25, left Chicago to join his girlfriend in New York last August, he had aspirations to act and to produce videos and a bachelor's degree in communications from DePaul University, but he didn't have a job. With his nest egg running on empty, he contacted a temp agency and was sent to IceStone, a manufacturer of countertop
title: ENTRY LEVEL; After Dreams of Acting, an Unexpected Role

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg raised his offer on Tuesday to universities interested in setting up a school of engineering and applied sciences in New York City: along with practically free use of a swath of land, the city will contribute as much as $100 million. Mr. Bloomberg publicly presented an invitation to universities to bid on the chance to
title: Bloomberg Pledges Up to $100 Million in City Aid to Develop an Engineering School

author: E-mail: metropolitan@nytimes.com; Ariel Kaminer is on leave.
body: I'm concerned that the Second Avenue subway project makes no allowance for personal teleportation modules. I'm worried that the new wing of the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, does not account for the possibility that films might someday be projected directly onto the backsides of our eyelids. Such stuff is troubling me because of a
title: CITY CRITIC; A Bridge Too Low And a Lesson For Visionaries

body: For more than three decades, Robert Vitaglione never turned down a client, representing thousands of immigrants in New York's overburdened federal immigration courts. But he is not a lawyer. He is a Roman Catholic priest without formal legal training or supervision -- and it showed. Disheveled and disorganized, Father Vitaglione sometimes
title: Removal of Priest's Cases Exposes Deep Holes in Immigration Courts

body: WHEN the sun glares down on the city, New Yorkers of means flee for the beach. Matt Kaye, a bar manager and D.J. who lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was such a refugee. He sat outside Rippers, a new grass-fed-burger shack that opened over the Memorial Day weekend, sipping an iced coffee. In the distance, a pod of surfers bobbed in the water,
title: Taking the A Train to Summer

body: PHILADELPHIA -- A package arrived on a shabby north Philadelphia block in January 2010, wrapped in Tyvek and measuring 55 feet long and 16 feet wide. Inside was a kitchenette, a bathroom and two bedrooms. The only thing missing was the toilet bowl lid. Just six weeks -- and 88 similar packages -- later, the Modules at Templetown, a four-story
title: SQUARE FEET; Squeezing Costs, Builders Take New Look at Prefab

body: For decades now, the pattern has been the same: New York City factories fall prey to the hunger for offbeat places to live, and once-gritty industrial neighborhoods like SoHo, TriBeCa, Dumbo and the meatpacking district are transformed into enviable residential enclaves. But in each evolution, there is a fraught, in-between moment when the factory
title: GREENPOINT JOURNAL; A Slaughterhouse in Brooklyn, and Misery Next Door

body: FOR more than five years, Julie Glickman lived in the ground-floor apartment of a Park Slope brownstone. The owners, family friends, lived upstairs. Ms. Glickman paid just $800 a month, and the rent never rose. The railroad-style apartment was charming, though dark. Ms. Glickman would have been happy staying there indefinitely, or at least ''until
title: THE HUNT; A Place With the Family Seal of Approval

body: This just in: Lt. M. K. Schwenk's first name was Milton, not Melton, as his obituary said. In 1899. His great-nephew, Dr. Daniel A. F. Schwenk, a retired dentist from Walpole, N.H., wrote to The Times last month, pointing out what he said were several errors in the 264-word obituary published on June 29, 1899. ''It's a tad late'' to bring them up,
title: CITY ROOM; Correction: An Obituary In 1899 Misstated ...

body: Once they were the shipshape town houses of the Brooklyn Navy Yard's senior officers, but now the gray buildings sit like ruins encountered in a jungle, their facades, roofs and interiors overgrown with ivy, weeds, even saplings. The punched-out windows and doors, rusted railings and vandalized rooms of Admiral's Row have become a blight in an
title: BROOKLYN NAVY YARD JOURNAL; A Battle Over Preservation in a Strip Once Worthy of Admirals

body: THE ballad of Kenyan Lewis and Grace Kelsey, were there a ballad of Kenyan and Grace, would be in part a song about stuff -- old stuff, rustic stuff, American stuff, stuff that was designed, above all, to be useful, but whose handsomeness grows more burnished with each passing year. Prop designers and dealers by trade, the two are collectors of
title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; American Rustic

body: The next engineering school in New York City could be a satellite campus of a university in Finland, South Korea or California, judging by the responses city officials received to their call for ideas on how to raise New York's profile in the realm of technological innovation. On Thursday, the city announced that it had received 18 expressions of
title: 18 Entrants Vie to Build New Campus On City Land

body: In a bid to cut costs at his star-crossed Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, the developer Bruce C. Ratner is pursuing plans to erect the world's tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 34-story tower that would fulfill his obligation to start building affordable housing at the site. The prefabricated, or modular, method he would use, which is
title: Atlantic Yards Plans to Build Tallest Prefab

body: Jessica Lynn Cohen and Andrew Jacob Weber are to be married Sunday afternoon at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Rabbi Leonard A. Schoolman is to officiate. The bride, 34, is the director of strategic planning in the consumer marketing group at Time Inc., where she analyzes growth opportunities for People and Sports Illustrated
title: Jessica Cohen, Andrew Weber

body: Suzanne Ross Sorkin and Robert Graham Susman were married Saturday evening at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs officiated. The bride, 30, works in Manhattan as a senior portfolio analyst in the real estate group of APG Asset Management, a Dutch firm. She buys and trades shares in real estate investment
title: Suzanne Sorkin, Robert Susman

author: Paul Berman is the author, most recently, of ''The Flight of the Intellectuals.''
body: THE NEOCONSERVATIVE PERSUASION Selected Essays, 1942-2009 By Irving Kristol Edited by Gertrude Himmelfarb. Foreword by William Kristol. 390 pp. Basic Books. $29.95. Irving Kristol, who died in 2009, is sometimes called the ''godfather'' or even ''father'' of neoconservatism, and the patriarchal honorific, like a well-worn hat, sits comfortably atop
title: Brute Reason

body: A 2-year-old boy was critically injured in Brooklyn on Tuesday night when he was hit by a van whose driver then fled the scene, the police said. The boy, whose name was not released, was struck about 6 p.m. at Kent and Flushing Avenues, a few blocks from the Brooklyn Navy Yard. According to the police, he was strapped into a stroller and was being
title: Boy Is Critically Hurt in Brooklyn Hit-Run
